title: 2025 Government Shutdown Impact Analysis
detail: Explore the cascading effects across economy, society, and politics

children.title: Economic Impact
children.detail: GDP losses, contractor effects, and market disruption

children.title: Economic Loss
children.detail: Each week of shutdown is estimated to reduce annualized quarterly GDP growth by about 0.1–0.2 percentage point; most activity rebounds after reopening (as of Oct 2025).

data.content: A shutdown pauses many discretionary activities (~6% of GDP in outlays). Forecasters estimate a 0.1–0.2 percentage point reduction in annualized quarterly GDP growth per week (as of Oct 2025).

visualization.source: S&P Global; Goldman Sachs Research, Oct 2025

children.source: S&P Global; Goldman Sachs Research, Oct 2025

children.title: GDP Breakdown
children.detail: Discretionary outlays represent roughly 6% of GDP, providing context for activities affected during a lapse (as of Oct 2025).

visualization.source: OMB historical tables; CBO background, Oct 2025

children.source: OMB historical tables; CBO background, Oct 2025

children.title: Consumer Confidence
children.detail: The CCI was 97.2 (Jul), 97.4 (Aug), and 94.2 (Sep) 2025; Oct/Nov values are projected values.
children.source: The Conference Board, Sep 2025

children.title: Financial Market Risks
children.detail: Market volatility can rise; ratings commentary may reference governance risks; IPO processing may be delayed when agencies limit operations (as of Oct 2025).

data.title: Stock volatility
data.detail: Some volatility indicators have risen during past lapses (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Ratings agency and market commentary, Oct 2025

data.title: Credit rating risk
data.detail: Rating agencies have cited shutdowns as a negative governance factor (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Ratings agency and market commentary, Oct 2025

data.title: IPO delays
data.detail: Offerings and approvals may be delayed while SEC operations are limited (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Ratings agency and market commentary, Oct 2025

children.title: Data & Reporting Delays
children.detail: Selected federal indicators can be delayed during a lapse (as of Oct 2025).

data.title: Economic releases suspended
data.detail: Jobs, GDP, and inflation reports may be delayed (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency contingency plans and prior shutdown precedents, Oct 2025

data.title: Census operations halted
data.detail: Some surveys may pause, depending on funding (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency contingency plans and prior shutdown precedents, Oct 2025

data.title: Trade data missing
data.detail: Import/export statistics can be delayed (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Direct and Indirect Effects
children.detail: Operational and market impacts linked to agency slowdowns (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Direct Effects
children.detail: Immediate impacts on workers, contractors, and certain services (as of Oct 2025).

data.title: Federal workers unpaid
data.detail: Hundreds of thousands of employees are furloughed; many essential personnel work with pay delayed (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.title: Contractors miss payments
data.detail: Back pay typically applies to federal employees, not contractors (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.title: Services halted
data.detail: Passports, some IRS operations, and park access can be paused or slowed (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

children.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

children.title: Indirect Effects
children.detail: Operational and market impacts linked to agency slowdowns (as of Oct 2025).

data.title: Household spending cuts
data.detail: Families may reduce discretionary purchases (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.title: Business uncertainty
data.detail: Some hiring and investment decisions are delayed (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.title: Tourism losses
data.detail: Access changes at national parks can affect nearby economies (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Small Business Stress
children.detail: Contractors and local businesses experience cash‑flow pressure (as of Oct 2025).

data.detail: Delayed invoices can force spending cuts (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.title: Community ripple effects
data.detail: Reduced foot traffic near federal hubs (as of Oct 2025).
data.source: Agency guidance; small business advocacy analyses, Oct 2025

data.detail: Most small firms lack back pay eligibility (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Political Context
children.detail: Congressional negotiations and procedural hurdles (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Negotiation Timeline
children.detail: Complete chronology of shutdown events

events.label: Sep 19, 2025
events.note: The House passes a 'clean' Continuing Resolution (CR). Senate Democrats oppose it, demanding inclusion of ACA tax credit extensions (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Sep 30, 2025
events.note: The Senate fails to advance competing funding proposals; a lapse in funding is expected at 12:01 a.m. EDT on Oct 1. House Speaker keeps House out of session (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 1, 2025 (12:01 am EDT)
events.note: Federal funding expires at 12:01 a.m. EDT, triggering a partial government shutdown. About 750,000 employees furloughed, 700,000 working without pay (as of Oct 14, 2025).

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Senate holds third vote on funding measures. Both Democratic and Republican versions fail (55–45 and 47–53). Preliminary negotiations described as 'productive discussion' (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 2, 2025
events.note: Department of Education staff report manipulated out-of-office emails blaming Democrats for shutdown, potential Hatch Act violation alleged (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 3, 2025
events.note: Senate holds fourth failed vote (54–44). Speaker Johnson extends House recess for another week, delaying Representative-elect swearing in (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 6, 2025
events.note: Senate holds fifth and sixth votes on competing proposals. Both fail again (45–55 and 52–42). President Trump claims talks underway; Senate Majority Leader Schumer denies (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 8, 2025
events.note: Shutdown extends to one week. Economic impacts begin accumulating. Smithsonian museums and National Zoo prepare for closure (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 10, 2025
events.note: Mass layoffs begin: At least 4,000 federal employees receive reduction-in-force (RIF) notices across seven agencies. Treasury, HHS, and Education most affected (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 13, 2025 (Day 13)
events.note: Shutdown reaches Day 13. Smithsonian museums, research centers, and National Zoo close. Speaker Johnson warns this could become longest shutdown in U.S. history (as of Oct 2025).
events.cost: Cultural institutions closed; economic damage escalating

events.label: Oct 14, 2025 (Day 14)
events.note: Senate returns for eighth vote on funding bill at 5:30 PM ET. Expected to fail again without 60-vote threshold. House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries calls evening meeting to explore solutions. President Trump directs Pentagon to pay troops; Coast Guard also to receive paychecks. Other federal workers await shutdown resolution (as of Oct 14, 2025).
events.cost: Day 14; approaching longest shutdown record (35 days)

visualization.source: Compiled events from congressional and agency reports, Sep–Oct 2025

children.source: Congressional records and major outlets, Sep–Oct 2025

children.title: Key Players
children.detail: President Trump, Congressional leaders

data.title: President Trump
data.detail: Directs executive priorities, negotiates funding, and drives immigration and budget policy.
data.source: White House and Congressional leadership statements, Oct 2025

data.title: Senate Leadership
data.detail: Majority Leader John Thune (R-SD) and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) steer Senate negotiations, debate, and major policy divisions.
data.source: White House and Congressional leadership statements, Oct 2025

data.title: House Leadership
data.detail: Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) and House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-LA) manage a narrow Republican majority. House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) leads opposition efforts to resolve shutdown through bipartisan negotiations (as of Oct 14, 2025).
data.source: White House and Congressional leadership statements, Oct 2025

children.source: White House and Congressional leadership statements, Oct 2025
Congressional records and major outlets, Sep–Oct 2025

children.title: Social Effects
children.detail: Vulnerable populations and community services disrupted

children.title: Nutrition & Food Security
children.detail: 6.7M+ at risk from WIC disruption; food assistance programs strained (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: WIC program at risk
data.detail: Serves 6.7 million pregnant women, mothers, and children under 5. USDA using $300 million tariff revenue for temporary funding through October, but long-term stability uncertain. Mississippi waitlisting new families; some tribal WIC programs exhausting funds (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: USDA, National WIC Association, PBS NewsHour, Politico, Oct 6-14 2025

data.title: SNAP benefits continue for now
data.detail: Food stamp benefits continue through existing funding authorities. Program operates as entitlement with mandatory funding, less affected by shutdown than WIC (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: FRAC, USDA, Food Research & Action Center, Oct 2025

data.title: School lunch programs at risk
data.detail: USDA Food and Nutrition Service operating with limited staff. National School Lunch Program and School Breakfast Program continue via mandatory funding but administrative support reduced. USDA's Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations facing disruptions (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: USDA, FRAC, tribal advocacy organizations, Oct 2025

children.source: USDA, National WIC Association, FRAC, PBS NewsHour, Oct 6-15 2025

children.title: Veterans & Military Families
children.detail: 15,000 VA staff furloughed; key services suspended (as of Oct 14, 2025)

data.title: VA services partially disrupted
data.detail: 15,000 of 460,000+ VA staff furloughed. Healthcare, disability, and pension payments continue via advance appropriations. Suspended: Transition Assistance Program, GI Bill Hotline (888-GIBILL-1), regional benefits offices, Native American Veterans Direct Loan Program, outreach services (as of Oct 14, 2025).
data.source: Department of Veterans Affairs, USA Today, The American Legion, Oct 14 2025

children.source: Department of Veterans Affairs, USA Today, The American Legion, Oct 14 2025

children.title: Tribal Communities
children.detail: 574 federally recognized tribes face treaty obligation violations (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: Tribal services severely impacted
data.detail: Federal shutdown violates trust and treaty obligations to 574 federally recognized tribes. Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe furloughed 25+ employees, closed museum and higher education dept. Tribes using scarce resources to fill federal gaps, straining budgets. Indian Health Services has advance appropriations but other tribal programs lack protection (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: NCAI, ABC News, Marketplace, Oct 2-13 2025

children.source: NCAI, ABC News, Marketplace, Oct 2-13 2025

children.title: Children & Early Learning
children.detail: Head Start programs threatened; child care subsidies stable short-term (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: Head Start programs threatened
data.detail: Early learning programs serving low-income children ages 0-5. Over 100 programs scheduled to receive grants Nov 1; disruption likely if shutdown continues. Programs using reserves or reducing services (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: HHS Office of Head Start, First Five Years Fund, Oct 13 2025

data.title: Child care subsidies stable short-term
data.detail: Child Care Development Block Grant forward-funded for FY2025, providing short-term protection. States have flexibility with 2-year obligation window. Federal workers struggle to afford care without paychecks; new bill proposes reimbursement for furloughed workers (as of Oct 13, 2025).
data.source: Action for Children, First Five Years Fund, WJLA, Oct 13 2025

children.source: HHS Office of Head Start, First Five Years Fund, Action for Children, Oct 13-15 2025

children.title: Housing & Energy Assistance
children.detail: Housing vouchers delayed; winter heating aid at risk (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: Housing assistance delayed
data.detail: HUD processing of new commitments and vouchers delayed. Section 8 and public housing operations continue but administrative functions slowed (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: HUD contingency plans, major outlets, Oct 2025

data.title: Low-income energy assistance delayed
data.detail: LIHEAP (Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program) processing and new applications delayed as winter heating season approaches. Vulnerable households face disconnections without federal aid (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: HHS contingency plans, state agencies, Oct 2025

children.source: HUD, HHS contingency plans, state agencies, Oct 2025

children.title: Disability & Healthcare Access
children.detail: SSA processing delayed; Medicaid enrollments slowed (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: Disability services slowed
data.detail: SSA continues disability payments but new application processing delayed. State agencies face staffing constraints affecting reviews and hearings (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: AAPD, SSA statements, Oct 2025

data.title: Medicaid processing slowed
data.detail: Medicaid payments continue as mandatory spending, but new enrollments, redeterminations, and state technical assistance from CMS delayed. Particularly impacts children's coverage transitions (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: CMS, state Medicaid agencies, Oct 2025

children.source: AAPD, SSA, CMS, state agencies, Oct 2025

children.title: Legal Aid & Rural Programs
children.detail: Civil legal assistance suspended; rural infrastructure projects halted (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: Legal aid services suspended
data.detail: Legal Services Corporation (independent nonprofit funded by Congress) facing funding delays. Low-income individuals lose access to civil legal assistance for housing, domestic violence, and family law matters (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: Legal Services Corporation, advocacy organizations, Oct 2025

data.title: Rural development programs halted
data.detail: USDA Rural Development loans and grants for housing, water systems, and community facilities suspended. Affects low-income rural communities waiting for infrastructure improvements (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: USDA Rural Development contingency plans, Oct 2025

children.source: Legal Services Corporation, USDA Rural Development, Oct 2025

children.title: Shutdown Sentiment
children.detail: Public concern over the federal shutdown (Washington Post, Oct 2025)

children.title: Healthcare & Public Health
children.detail: Medical and public health services disrupted (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: CDC monitoring reduced
data.detail: Approximately 600 CDC employees terminated. Disease surveillance and health communication programs hobbled. Some divisions report 'nobody to answer the phone' (as of Oct 14, 2025).
data.source: NPR, CNN, Nature, Oct 14 2025

data.title: NIH research paused
data.detail: Clinical trials delayed, patient enrollment suspended during shutdown (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: HHS statements, major outlets, Oct 2025

data.title: Medicare delays
data.detail: 50% of CMS personnel furloughed, longer wait times for beneficiary services (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: CMS contingency plans, major outlets, Oct 2025

children.source: NPR, CNN, HHS, CMS, Oct 14-15 2025

children.title: Tourism & Cultural Impacts
children.detail: Parks, museums, and cultural sites closed (as of Oct 15, 2025)

data.title: National parks closed
data.detail: Operations reduced or access limited. Popular destinations closed affecting tourism-dependent communities (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: National Park Service statements, major outlets, Oct 2025

data.title: Smithsonian closures
data.detail: All 21 Smithsonian museums, research centers, and National Zoo closed Oct 12 after exhausting prior-year funds. Affects nearly 17 million annual visitors. National Gallery of Art also closed (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: ABC News, New York Times, Smithsonian Institution, Oct 12 2025

data.title: Weather warnings reduced
data.detail: NWS prioritizes essential warnings; some services may be limited during shutdown (as of Oct 15, 2025).
data.source: NOAA statements, major outlets, Oct 2025

children.source: NPS, Smithsonian, NOAA, ABC News, New York Times, Oct 12-15 2025
USDA, HHS, VA, NCAI, Smithsonian, major outlets, Oct 1-15 2025

children.title: Military & Security
children.detail: Defense and security operations continue; pay is delayed during lapses (as of Oct 2025).

children.title: Military Personnel
children.detail: Active duty and security forces work unpaid

data.title: Active duty unpaid
data.detail: 1.3M military personnel work without paychecks
data.source: DoD; DHS; FAA statements, Oct 2025

data.title: Air traffic control stress
data.detail: Controllers work mandatory overtime unpaid
data.source: DoD; DHS; FAA statements, Oct 2025

data.title: Border security gaps
data.detail: CBP agents, Coast Guard operate at reduced capacity
data.source: DoD; DHS; FAA statements, Oct 2025

DoD; DHS; FAA statements, Oct 2025
